docs.snippet: Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton held a four percentage point lead over Republican Donald Trump in the ABC News/Washington Post poll released on Monday, one day before the U.S. presidential election....
docs.lead_paragraph: Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton held a four percentage point lead over Republican Donald Trump in the ABC News/Washington Post poll released on Monday, one day before the U.S. presidential election.

headline.main: Clinton Leads Trump 47-43 Percent in White House Race: Washington Post/ABC Poll
headline.print_headline: Clinton Leads Trump 47-43 Percent in White House Race: Washington Post/ABC Poll

docs.snippet: A bus and rail strike in Philadelphia that had threatened to hamper voter turnout at Tuesday's U.S. presidential election has ended after workers reached a deal with the transport authority, the two sides said on Monday....
docs.lead_paragraph: A bus and rail strike in Philadelphia that had threatened to hamper voter turnout at Tuesday's U.S. presidential election has ended after workers reached a deal with the transport authority, the two sides said on Monday.

headline.main: Philadelphia Transit Strike Ends One Day Before Presidential Election
headline.print_headline: Philadelphia Transit Strike Ends One Day Before Presidential Election

headline.main: Trump Dolls on Sale in Moscow Ahead of U.S. Election

docs.snippet: A Reuters/Ipsos tracking poll released on Friday put Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton just 5 percentage points above Republican rival Donald Trump ahead of Tuesday's U.S. presidential election. But major bookmakers and online exchan...
docs.lead_paragraph: A Reuters/Ipsos tracking poll released on Friday put Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton just 5 percentage points above Republican rival Donald Trump ahead of Tuesday's U.S. presidential election. But major bookmakers and online exchanges are much more confident about a Clinton victory.

headline.main: Factbox: Where the Bookies and Trading Exchanges Put Trump, Clinton Odds
headline.print_headline: Factbox: Where the Bookies and Trading Exchanges Put Trump, Clinton Odds

docs.snippet: Plunging print ad sales and an explosion of online outlets spreading inaccurate information threaten to diminish, and in some cases extinguish, the impact of traditional media companies....
docs.lead_paragraph: Plunging print ad sales and an explosion of online outlets spreading inaccurate information threaten to diminish, and in some cases extinguish, the impact of traditional media companies.
docs.abstract: Jim Rutenberg Mediator column laments fate of good journalism after presidential election ends; notes many credible news organizations are planning cutbacks, assuming current bump in readership and advertising will disappear at conclusion of politically contentious race; fears situation will leave Americans without counter to dubious news circulating on social media.

headline.main: Media’s Next Challenge: Overcoming the Threat of Fake News
headline.print_headline: Journalism’s Next Challenge: Overcoming the Threat of Fake News

docs.snippet: Traditional network “decision desks” will be joined this year by digital challengers aiming to shed light on an often opaque vote-data process....

headline.main: TV Networks Face a Skeptical Public on Election Night
headline.print_headline: TV Networks Are Facing a Skeptical Audience  During Election Night

docs.snippet: In the final days of the 2016 campaign, Hillary Clinton holds advantages over Donald Trump in just enough states to win her the White House — if she can hold them on Election Day....
docs.lead_paragraph: In the final days of the 2016 campaign, Hillary Clinton holds advantages over Donald Trump in just enough states to win her the White House — if she can hold them on Election Day.

docs.lead_paragraph: Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump told crowds in Michigan and Minnesota on Sunday his administration would not admit refugees without local support, using appearances in states with growing Muslim communities to criticize Democrat Hillary Clinton's support for accepting people fleeing Syria.

docs.snippet: In the place where America's democracy took root, with tens of thousands shivering in the cold, Barack and Michelle Obama passed the torch Monday to Hillary Clinton in an emotional but anxious plea to elect her president....
docs.lead_paragraph: In the place where America's democracy took root, with tens of thousands shivering in the cold, Barack and Michelle Obama passed the torch Monday to Hillary Clinton in an emotional but anxious plea to elect her president.

headline.main: As Campaign Closes, the Obamas Pass the Torch to Clinton
